title: Knife crime is soaring fastest in areas OUTSIDE London
text:
Knife crime in rising in towns across England and Wales as the problem is spreads from big cities, shocking statistics show.

Analysis of crime figures shows that some of the highest rises around the UK have come away from London, where an ever-growing murder toll has raised the profile of the issue.

The number of incidents has more than doubled in Oldham in the last two years, while it is up by 90% in both Norwich and Milton Keynes, 60% in Slough and increased by 40% in Blackpool.

This map (left) shows how knife crime is rising across the country outside the capital despite the number of suspects being charged falling

But while the problem gets worse, with an 81% rise in incident, the number of people charged over knife offences is down by 20%.

New data obtained by the BBC shows that Slough, Blackpool and Oldham have joined areas of Manchester, Birmingham and London in the worst 20 areas for knife crime rate.

London still has 16 of the 25 worst-hit areas, with rural Cornwall and Norfolk the areas with the lowest number of incidents.

The age with the largest number of both victims and suspects is the 25 to 34 years old bracket, with 18 to 24-year-olds the second hardest hit.

Earlier this year, official government statistics showed that the five areas which saw the highest increases in knife crime were Suffolk (up 51%), Merseyside (up 49%), Dyfed-Powys (up 45%), Lancashire: (up 33%) and North Yorkshire (up 31%).

But more detailed analysis has been able to identify specific towns where the problem is worst.

A security guard at a Jobcentre in Liverpool became the latest victim of the UK's knife crime epidemic today. He is currently in a stable condition in hospital

Earlier this year, Barnardo's chief executive Javed Khan called for more action, saying: 'It's unacceptable that the knife crime crisis continues unabated with offences at record levels.

'Children are not born with knives in their hands, knife crime is a symptom of a much bigger problem.

'Our frontline support services say vulnerable children and young people are being recruited and exploited by criminal gangs and forced to traffic drugs and carry knives.

'Urgent action must be taken so that future generations are not condemned to live in an endless spiral of violence.'
